We did book the rooms for Nov. 6 at a price of $130.00 and on Nov. 7 the price was $165.00, we could not believe they on a wednesday they charged us $175.00 plus taxes.

Nov 9 2009 	The Monte Carlo is a breath of fresh air!	At the end of the day after touring the streets and hotels on the strip, it was always niceto come back to the Monte Carlo. It is elegant. The lobbies, hallways smell like fresh flowers and CLEAN (not smoky). Coming back always felt like a reprieve from the craziness of the strip! Our room was 'fine'. Stayed for 3 nights and the housekeeping service wasn't spectacular, we found surfaces and floors were not clean upon return each day. The room attendants also make a lot of noise in the mornings vacuuming the halls and knocking on doors. Finally, the walls are thin, and we had to listen to the neighbors partying in bed!The pool area is lovely, but keep in mind it closes at 5pm SHARP. (Music off, bar closed and we were literally thrown out of the hottub by the lifeguard staff). We were hoping to enjoy the hottub in the early evening under the stars, but it seems all pools and hottubs in Vegas close early, for safety reasons we guess.The Monte Carlo is central to everything, and we would definitely stay there again!

Nov 7 2009 	Enjoyed every minute of our stay	We spent 3 nights at the Monte Carlo and enjoyed every minute. Check-in was quick, and the desk clerk was friendly and helpful. We arrived at 11 a.m. and were in our room 20 minutes later. He gave us a room near the elevators, as requested, because my husband has trouble walking. We like to sleep in on vacation and one day didn't leave the room until 1 p.m., but the housekeepers respected the Do Not Disturb sign and somehow managed to clean the room as soon as we were gone. They did a great job--our room was sparkling clean every day. 8 of us met for the Sunday brunch buffet and spent a few hours there visiting, but the wait staff never seemed impatient and the food was great! The fitness room was well-equipped, and I appreciated the free water and juice. Only one small complaint--the daily resort fee covers just 1 trip to the fitness room per day. If I wanted to use the weights in the morning and go back later for the treadmill, it was an extra $5. That seems ridiculous to me, but it's a pretty small thing compared to all the other great things about this hotel. We'll definitely stay there again.

Nov 6 2009 	FIRST TIME IN VEGAS AND LOVED THE MONTE CARLO	My boyfriend and I went to Vegas for the first time Oct 2-7th. We had origanally choose to stay at one of the fancier hotels, but later decided on the Monte Carlo because of the good price. We were more than happy with what we got!!! The Monte Carlo is deffiantly not one of the top notch luxary hotels, but it was exactly what we needed. The rooms were basic, but suffecient. We paid extra to have a high room /strip view. Not necessary, but it was a great view. The room was a bit on the small side. Similar to what you would have at a Holiday Inn, but it was clean and enjoyable. The bed was comfortable and the sheets clean. Did not enjoy the 9.50 service charge per day for the "luxary's" of the room, such as room service, 2 small waters fresh daily, and local newspaper daily. I was highly impressed with the fact that the shower was probably the best that I had ever been in, in a hotel. Great water pressure and no lack of hot water, even when the 2 other people in the room with me showered first. Overall, great value for room. Although I was in awe over some of the other hotels such as the bellagio, and venetian, I would stay at the Monte Carlo any day over them! The Monte Carlo is a smaller hotel/casino, but for us that was exactly what we wanted. I never got lost in our hotel, like I did in the majority of the other larger hotels. By the end of our first night there I basically new where all the resturants and food courts were, and could easily make it up to our room within a few minutes. In some of the larger hotels, such as the MGM, Bellagio and Venetian you can literrally get lost and walk around for an hour before you find what you are looking for. Such a waste of time when you are in VegasLocation was GREAT!!!!! I loved where we were!! Not quite in the middle of the strip, but directley accross the street from the bus stop at the MGM Grand where you could buy day and week passes. Also, directly across from a couple ticket stands where you could get discount tickets for shows for the day. This was always our first stop where we would make our plans for the day. Last, there is a Denny's right across the street where you can get breakfast for cheap!As for the resturants in the hotel, we had the opportunity to visit 2. We ate lunch at the newley branded "Pub". Ordered 2 build your own burgers and 2 domestic beers a peice. The burgers were probably the best we ever had, HUGE, and just overall delious!! They however do not list their prices on the menu, and this should have been my first clue to try something different! The burger and fries were 25.00 a peice and 5.00 domestic draft beers. This came to a 75.00 dollar tab!! Was not expecting that! We did also go to "The Buffet" for breakfast one morning and it was good. A lot to choose from, but nothing to extraordianary. Prices are deffaintly cheaper for the buffet during the week. Over all, we had a GREAT experience at the Monte Carlo and would deffeintly stay there again because of the value that we got for our money, the size of the hotel, and the great location! Would not recommend it to the 20 something that is going to Vegas to stay up all night and party because for the most part it was fairly quite, but would deffaintly recommend it to the people who are there to sight see and take Las Vegas in and get a good rest at night!

Nov 4 2009 	Brilliant Week	We had been to Las Vegas twice before staying at the Excalibur and the Luxor. After spending a week travelling to Arizona and Utah we were spending our last week in Vegas to celebrate a friends wedding. Members of the party were staying at the Bellagio, Wynne, New York New York and Luxor, but we were looking for the best deal in a reasonable hotel and the Monte Carlo seemed the best option. Initially we had booked for 8 nights but arrived in Vegas a night earlier and the service desk were very helpful in accommodating us. Our room was a bit dated but clean. The Monte Carlo looks very impressive from the outside and is spacy inside it is also ideally situated on the strip. There are cheap eating and drinking options which the upmarket hotels do not have. We tried the buffet at lunch and it was very good. There was building work going on between the hotel and the Bellagio which we didnt here but it was a pain having to walk through it. Our friends and the bride and groom were staying at the Bellagio so we did spend a lot of time at that hotel which is very luxurious but also expensive for drinks etc. so they were joining us at the Monte Carlo in the evening. We would return to the Monte Carlo as we found it hard to fault, perhaps new decor!

Nov 3 2009 	Great place for Vegas getaway	You don't go to Vegas to hang out in your room and for that reason the Monte Carlo is PERFECT! Not that the rooms are bad, they are just average. Spacious, with comfortable beds and clean and nice washroom. But the best part is this hotel is a great price, is amazing location and has a lovely pool area. Would definitely recommend!!

Nov 2 2009 	Halloween for Adults	Staff friendly at check in, Pub bar and at the Buffet. Paid extra for a high floor with a view, but disappointed because city center blocked more than half of the strip view. Room was clean, but worn out sheets and bed covers were pilled. In room movies were not up to date, I guess 6 months or a year old. Internet was 14.99 for 24hrs. Wireless was very low and wired did not work. My room needed serious updating. I liked the in room safe. Bell service was quick and friendly. I missed the microbrewery. The in room phone was so old that none of their services were listed. You had to dial the operator to get the right extension. Housekeeping was professional and courteous.

Nov 1 2009 	TAKE A CHANCE ON THE MONTE CARLO	Four of us stayed between the 25th October and the 30th October, and had a great time. I have previously stayed at the Venetian, obviously the Monte Carlo is nowhere near the Venetian in luxury. However it is over half the price. Our rooms on the 25th Floor overlooked the pool, and the soon to be open City Centre Site. We had no problems with construction noise as the project is almost complete. However the new buildings cast a shadow over the pool area for a large part of the day, so if lazing by the pool is your thing you may want to go elsewhere. I had a problem with the safe in my room. This was quicky fixed by the friendly security staff. The rooms do need some modernisation but are clean and have everything you need. The hotel is not themed so it does not attract large amounts of gawping tourists, just guests and gamblers. The buffet is ok, but the close by MGM Grand is better. The hotel also includes a food court, with Starbucks, Macdonalds, Subway and a few others. The hotel is in a good position on the strip. Don't buy food or drink from the hotel shop, pop outside to the CVS Pharmacy or Walgreens and you will save loads. The MGM Grand across the road will give you access to the Monorail, but if there are a few of you, it may be cheaper and quicker to get a taxi. To sum up, The Monte Carlo is not the best hotel on the strip but very good value for money. Our room cost $340 for 5 nights, which at this time is 207. This is excellent value.

Nov 1 2009 	Better than Functional	Stayed for 5 nights in Vegas for the first time. The place itself has to be seen, as does the Grand Canyon. The hotel was less obviously themed than some on The Strip. It was pleasant but has no "wow" factor. It seemd big, but is smaller than some nearby. It is essentially functional abnd 'does what it says on the tin' We had breakfast over the road @ Denny's, which is better value and probably better quality, than what's on offer in the Cafe or the Buffet within the hotel itself. There are all the usual fast food outlets on site too, but was of little or no interest to us beyond Starbuck's for a takeaway coffee. There's a massive construction next door a "city within a city" as was described to us. I think all the noisy part of that is now over, but the hotel has a procession of hard hatted, high-vis. jacketed workers filling most of the middle quality or fast food outlets during the day as they take their breaks. It does not enhance any attempt @ ambience. Some of the day-to-day manitainance taking place was also a bit obtrusive, lots of screened off area and painting going on."The Pub" an on site restaurant, does very reasonable burgers and steaks with all the usual immense quantities. It finishes serving @: 10.00 p.m. which we felt was a tad early for a city that doesn't sleep.Movement around the hotel is helped by a clever multi-lift arrangement i.e. certain floor sequences from certain lift areas, it seemed very efficient.The room was big, basic mostly quite clean. The toiletries were non-decsript and a tad mean. No bath robes, but I guess in a hotel that size, maybe they'd be pinched at a rate of knots. Ice machine down the corridor and a freebie USA Today newspaper each day was a nice touch. The hotel from other reviews has a reputation for being noisy, thin walls etc. People being raucous outside and next door could occassionally disturb, but it wasn't that bad.The Bellagio next door just gave off a classier feel as did Cesar's Palace. The Casino again was functional and okay, compared to say the hotels like The Sahara and The Stratosphere in the North and very scruffy part of town, which smelt of fast food, pop-corn and candy floss.The pool with its river ring ride and waves was fine, but not as splendid as the near neighbours already mentioned.We had a great view from our room. There was little to disappoint, but thereare unsurpisingly better hotels.Ray and SandraOrpington

Oct 30 2009 	We used to love the Monte Carlo	My family came to Vegas to celebrate my mom-in-laws 80th birthday. We usually stay at the Monte Carlo due to the service, rooms and location. Within a few steps, you have several casinos to visit and the Rosewood Grille is right across the street. We normally have had great luck with the Monte Carlo, but this trip might be our last stay.It all started at check in. The still have people getting into a variety of lines to get to the front desk. Instead of one line and you get the next available person, you get into a line and hope you pick the right one. I, of course, did not. I watched as people who came in after me go to the front desk staff while I stood and stood. I only had 3 single people in front of me, but of course, as they got the desk, 2  4 others joined them. So after a 20 minute wait, I was finally at the front desk.I booked this trip over 6 months ago asking for connecting rooms, one with a king, one with two queens. Of course, they could not do this. I had options of a king in a handicap room on a different floor from the 2nd room or two rooms that were both queens in various sections of the same floor. After some work, they were finally able to get us two rooms, both queens, close to one another. You would think with todays technology, the planning for rooms would not be this difficult. So after 30 minutes, we were finally up to our room. The rooms were okay. I remember the Monte Carlo having nicer rooms, but I guess they are just getting old. What was really disappointed is the condition of the room from the cleaning staff. All the beds looked like, after they were made, someone laid in the middle of the beds. The comforters were wrinkled and in one case, the pillows were on the bed, not under the comforter. So we spent the first part of our visit looking the room over to ensure it had actually been cleaned.The first evening and day was nice. The casino was clean, getting around was easy and the staff at the hotel were courteous. They cleaned our rooms as expected and the room seemed to be in good shape, until we went to bed. In one of the room, the sheets did not fit either queen bed. It was like some camping trip where you got your bed short sheeted. We tried to strip and remake the beds, but it did not matter. Oct 25 2009 	Perfect Hotel for our vacation!	Myself, my father and brother stayed at the Monte Carlo for 4 nights October 19-23 and couldn't have asked for a better hotel. Great show, very lively.Anyhow, I've stayed at many of the big properties in vegas, like the MGM Grand, Paris, etc., and the Monte Carlo is definately a great place to stay, we will go back for sure.One tip I can leave for people is: have a good time in vegas dont get wrapped up by the reviews and whatnot. you vacation is what you make it. Oct 20 2009 	Simply an amazing experience.	I arrived at the Monte Carlo around 10:30PM and it took about 10 minutes to check in with no problems, oh and I love hearing "You already paid for the room, we don't need to have your card on file, unless you want movies or something." We get up to the room and its HUGE! (2 Queen beds a non-smoking). The other pool is nice as well, as is the jacuzzi.The service is what made this place amazing, I had a shirt on bed that I left there, I left the room to get a bite to eat, I come back and guess what the SHIRT IS FOLDED on the bed, I've never had a maid do that before.The food-court is open 24 hours but kind of pricey, for instance a foot long turkey sandwich and Subway was $9.00. If you ask the front desk for coupons upon check-in however, you can get a free soda or something with purchase.The one complaint I had was that the air conditioning unit in the room was in-wall and controlled by a thermostat in the room, you can set it to 60 and fan Hi, and it takes a while to get cold but its not loud so I guess that's good.Could use some more TV channels and also about the noise from the pool DJ, I had a room on the other side and didn't hear it. Oct 20 2009 	Third time lucky but then you get what you pay for	The Monte Carlo is a good on strip hotel, not fantastic, not awful, but good. I called the front desk and they moved us to a non smoking floor immediately. Our second room albeit slightly better had two Queen size beds again which to be frank is useless to a couple and takes up a lot of the floor space. I called the front desk and asked to be moved again to a room with a single King size bed. The front desk told me they couldn't do this for the first evening but were able to the next day. Finally, the next day we got a room that was ideal, a king size bed, and plenty of floor space for luggage, shopping etc. Throughout the experience I do have to say the front desk were accommodating and helpful at every turn.As for the remainder, the Pub has had a makeover and the Beer Towers have gone which is a bit of a bind as they made the old micro brewery worth a visit. I didn't use the pools but did go out there a couple of times, unfortunately you don't get much sun late on in the afternoon as the new building adjacent do their best to block out the sunlight. The Casino itself was ok, free craps lessons every day at 11. Occasional $5 blackjack tables for those gambling on a budget but I have to give special mention to Gail, one of the blackjack dealers. Her friendly demeanor really made playing at the table a pleasure, she introduced us to several people from all over the world and the table had a great atmosphere.There's also a Starbucks at the back of the Casino for those in need of a morning coffee, one thing I would say is the queues here get pretty big and you may have a wait so if you need a fix it might be quicker to go to NYNY next door.All in all, the location is on strip and pretty good but not central, the cleanliness and service are as you would expect from any hotel. My only gripe would be the rooms as they could probably do with being touched up but overall, we booked 90 days in advance and so got a good discount and on the strength of that it was a great value for money location and I wouldn't have any qualms staying in this hotel again.

Oct 18 2009 	dont bother	poor attitude by staff along with poor but expensive facilities.dont try and get a sunbed after 11am as the60 or so that arent in the shade will already be taken.if you are lucky and do manage to get one it will either be dirty or broken.dont sign for anything at the bar etc as we found a 30dollar tip had been added to our bill at andre's even though we left a 15 dollar tip.we were then told by staff that it was a slip of the pen on our behalf.its 19 dollars to use the gym plus 5dollars for the changing rooms.dont bother with the reopened pub two lots of fish and chips with a couple of beersis over 60dollars with tax.the rooms are large but very basic with thin walls leading to you listening to next doors noise. terry .uk

Oct 18 2009 	Good hotel great layout good value	Stayed at this hotel at the end of September for a week, having previously stayed at the Luxor, Circus Circus, the Flamingo and Ballys. We chose here for a change and got a good rate for the week and we were not disappointed. Many of the hotels in Las Vegas are great but the layout is so complicated you can get lost in them. Thats where this hotel was a pleasant change. The casino was basically all one long room, the places to eat, the sports book and the bars were easy to find. The elevators came out near to the Pool and the food court so you could never get lost. We upgraded to a high floor room with a strip view for $20 dollars a night. We were the very end room in the corridor (335)and the strip view was ok, but the windows were really dirty ( I think the end room gets all the dirt from the construction next door- the room our friends were in next door to us had much cleaner windows). I would not pay to upgrade again. Anyway, the room was clean and tidy but a bit dated, with some of the furniture a bit shabby around the edges and perhaps in need of a refurb. As we faced out onto the strip it was also a little noisy (even on the 30th floor), so if you dont sleep well choose a room at the back. However, for the amount of time you spend in a room in Vegas it was fine. There was a good system for the elevators, although were were on the 30th floor, the elevators were split into groups according to the floors they serviced. Our set of lifts only stopped from floor 24 upwards so it never took long to get to the room. Most of the food court was 24 hour as was the very good 'Cafe' in the hotel. While we were there the 'Cafe' also served Steak and Eggs from midnight till 6am for just $5.99. We all tried it the one evening and the steak was very good and came with hash browns and toast, the service was also very good in the cafe, although perhaps a little slow to get the bill at the end of the 'Steak and Eggs' meal. The hotel has a good lively bar and eatery called Diablo's which has a mexican theme and opens out onto the strip. They also have a happy hour there from 3-7. The pool area was great with a lazy river, a wave pool, a normal pool and a very hot jaccuzzi . The cocktails were an average of 10 or 11 dollars by the pool, which is a little expensive but they were good. you can hire inner tubes for the lazy river for 15 dollars a day, but you can buy them at the pool shop for just $10.81 which includes them re-inflating them if necesary. The only downside with the pool area was most of it was in the shade till about 11am (probably due to the new construction of the high rise 'City centre' next door and also the time of year we were there). We tried the Chines Noodle restaurant in the hotel also, the food and service was good but the wine was a little expensive.All in all, we had a great week at the Monte Carlo and would certainly stop there again.

Oct 14 2009 	Plenty of elbow room	Stayed for 5 days and 4 nights. The location on the strip is great..not too overly busy, like places right in the middle of the strip but also not far away either to all the interesting places to visit.This hotel has plenty of staff for checking in and out so theres not alot of waiting around. We had an 8th floor room,.. not much for a view on the backside but you can get a partial glimpse of the pool(s) below. Very spacious room, low lighting and thick heavy covers on the bed. good sized bathroom with plenty of towels and toiletries. One drawback is that they want to charge for WiFi service, which we believe is just ridiculous because there are much cheaper hotels across the country and places that give you this service for free anymore. They also need to install stationary or ceiling fans in the rooms as the window can only be opened a couple of inches and the room was stuffy in the morning. good bathroom with plenty of towels and guest toiletries. Housekeeping was very good, even in the latter part of the day, as you can find someone in the hallway if you need anything. The Casino itself was very nice and is wide open with alot of games. we found, compared to many other casinos on the Strip, that this one was much more open for foot traffic and had plenty of elbow room without feeling overly crowded, which was nice. We found the waitresses were very slow in bringing drinks unless you tipped heavy and heard that complaint from other people as well during our stay but outside of that, the casino itself is very well layed out. Their is a McDonalds, a Subway and another fastfood business in the hotel adjacent to the casino for quick bites. The breakfast buffet is actually pretty good for the price and the main selling point here, is the made to order omelettes...they also have a great variety of fruits and fresh baked goods to go along with a typical breakfast buffet tho we didnt see any toast but they had biscuits. I wouldnt recommend the lunch or dinner buffets here for the price, as there are so many buffets along the strip that offer more variety at the same price range but thats my personal observation. We did experience Diablos Cantina, which is a pub belonging to the hotel and casino..here you can sit outside on a patio setting and enjoy a cocktail, listen to music and people watch right on the corner of Las Vegas Blvd and Monte Carlo. The chicken nachos are fantastic and a house favorite but be prepared to be full.. our waitress gave us a good tip and recommended getting only one order because the serving size is so large, it will feed four easily.. we tried our best and maybe finished a third of it and they are sooo good. The pool(s) area is quite popular and the Lazy River located here is just what it sounds like.. you can rent a floaty, grab a cocktail from the poolside bar and float around on the slow moving river all day if you want. its depth is only three feet or so but it will move you. some may want to come early to sunbathe as the lounge chairs fill up pretty fast after high noon when the sun comes around the building to shine on the pool area. Overall this hotel and casino has good points and bad too but it ranks up there with many of the leading places in Las Vegas and the architecture is amazing in itself for picture taking. There are good pictures of this property online.The staff, both in the hotel and casino are very helpful and super courteous to everyone, answering questions or giving advise to those that need it, whether a guest or just visiting. Be prepared to spend alot more for small items you might need from vendors inside as they are quite pricey unless you hit the jackpot or just have money to burn. we found for simple items that wont break your budget, you can walk a couple hundred yards nearby the property to a local CVS or Walgreens store and use the savings in the casino or for whatever.

Oct 8 2009 	It's a beige sort of place.....but thats not always bad!	Stayed 3 nights at MC from the 1stOctober checking out on the 4th. I'd read a few bad reports of this hotel, so I was a little aprehensive about my stay, however, given it was a comp deal, I went ahead with my stay....and I'm glad I did....The Monte Carlo Hotel is a pretty nice hotel and not deserving of some of the bad reviews I have seen posted.As a solo female traveller I can say I felt totally safe and comfortable at the MC. Check in was swift and friendly. I was given room 20318 which faced the mountains....with the Orleans seen in the distance straight ahead and the NYNY to my left.The room....as with the hallways was decorated in beige. The carpets could do with a freshen up but the bed was very comfortable, the linens were crisp and not at all scratchy, the towels in the bathroom were brand new and fluffy white. The room is furnished with "cherry wood"...it is looking a tad outdated for my taste, however, the desk wardrobe and amoir were all in excellent condition. The room was very clean and comfortable over all.The 1st night I heard no noise at all...and I wondered where the reviews of paper thin walls come from. I found out on the second day when I had 2 ladies move into the room next door who were LOUD....very loud...I could hear every word of their conversation! I had a room with an interconnecting door though....so that might be to be avoided.The casino downstairs has a wonderfully staffed, friendly poker room. The slot machines varied from pennies up and the cocktail service was super speedy sometimes and deathly slow at others, depending on which section you sit in. There is a food court with a starbucks and subway, maccas, sbaro, ice creams and some chinese food and mexican food.The location of MC is slap bang next to NYNY on one side and the city center project on the other. I did not hear any construction noise at all. The pool area has 2 pools and a lazy river. Well staffed and very clean.Room service is amongst the worst I have eaten anywhere....this is to be avoided....I ordered twice just to make sure I didnt just cop a bad night....and the 2nd time was equally as bad as the 1st.....give room service a miss.Over all though....I consider the Monte Carlo a pretty good 3 star hotel. It may not have the glitz and glamour of other big players in the Vegas Hotel game, but it also doesnt have the high rates. It's a solid mid teir property with friendly staff, good location and pretty good bang for your buck.Would I stay there again? Yes. Would I suggest friends stay there? Yes....for a rate of under $100 a night....it's a pretty good deal.....anything over $100, there are better deals to be had in Vegas.Oh...ps...They have introduced a "resort fee", which I think is rubbish....it's $9.50 a night (I think)...I wrote "declined" under where it says resort fee on my check in slip. It was not charged to by bill upon check out.shirl'

Oct 7 2009 	Watch the "Resort Fee"	Like a lot of hotels this one charges a $10/day "Resort Fee" for the health club, bottled water in the room , etc. I did not use any of these services. Oct 6 2009 	It was okay except for the pool area and weird garage	I recently visited the Monte Carlo for the first time and stayed through the weekend. I got a good deal on Hotwire.Although built in 1993, the Monte Carlo has been well-maintained over the years and was in good shape. Hallways, lobby, elevators, and room all have a consistent design scheme and look good. The room was well-designed, attractive, and in good condition, with no funny smells or damage, except for a small tan stain on one of the comforters. The room was quiet and I got a good night's sleep. Room A/C was quiet and maintained temperature well. Parking is free, there is a lot of it, and the garage is relatively new and looks a lot nicer than some of the garages attached to older hotels on the Strip. Landscaping is not as elaborate as the Bellagio but is decent and reasonably attractive. Plus they have "free" newspapers (well, considering how much this place costs, they should be handing out newspapers). And of course, it's on the Strip and conveniently located next to a CVS/pharmacy open 24/7.There are some downsides, though, which is why I can't give it a rating of five. As a lot of people have noted, there's no fridge in the rooms. The room lighting was kind of dim and inadequate (only two lamps). There's an annoying $9 daily resort fee (which with taxes comes to $10.50 a day). The Monte Carlo uses the same gigantic garage for valet parking, self parking, and employee parking for both itself and the adjacent CityCenter complex, so the garage has a very confusing design intended to keep all four user populations separate, and the signage is not clear, which means it's easy to end up going the wrong way. The pool area is too small and in the shade of the Monte Carlo building itself for much of the day, which means the pools are rather cold and the surrounding chairs are overcrowded. The music in the pool area was not as loud as I expected but I agree that it is annoying. In the end, I appreciated the convenience of staying in a pleasant, clean, comfortable, quiet hotel room on the Strip with a good view of the city. But if you also like to go swimming during a Vegas vacation, the Monte Carlo is not a good choice.

Sep 9 2009 	Would not stay here again	The Monte Carlo was not awful, but our room smelled like industrial cleaner and the sheets did not fit the bed. Sep 3 2009 	Very enjoyable stay - will definitely stay here again!	I dont know why some Las Vegas hotels avoid using any kind of organized line management system for the check in process, and the Monte Carlo is one of them. It seems that you have to jockey for a position in front of the check in desk, and pray that the clerks are efficient or that the people ahead of you dont have credit card issues. I hate that they dont use the next in line approach by setting up the customary velvet ropes to guide guests through the line in an orderly manner. That said however, our stay at the Monte Carlo was GREAT once we got to our room. The rooms are nicely updated, clean and comfortable, the bathroom is super-clean with great amenities, and the hotel atmosphere is very nice. Housekeeping was excellent and the hotel towels were plush. The only downside to the room was the thin walls but this is common in most hotels and would have gone unnoticed except that the couple in the room next to us was rowdy and obnoxious - the lady had a loud, irritating laugh - but I chalk that up to inconsiderate human behavior and poor manners, and nothing against the hotel itself. Laughter is good, but not a 3:00 AM when some people are trying to sleep! Lucky for us they were gone the last two nights. We ate at the Monte Carlo buffet two times, for breakfast and then again for dinner but not on the same day. Both meals were excellent with a wide variety of fresh and tasty foods to choose from. Breakfast had traditional choices of eggs and bacon but also had pork chops and other meats although we could not seem to find any toast, and if you are an oatmeal eater like me, the raisins were located at the salad bar, and there was no brown sugar. The shrimp selection at dinnertime was fresh and the shrimp were large. The desserts were yummy as usual. The days of the cheap buffet are long gone in Las Vegas, but at Monte Carlo the best part about eating the buffet there was the relatively low price: breakfast was about $12 each and dinner was around $19 each. There is a food court which came in handy when my Starbucks craving hit, and for pizza from Sbarro as a late night snack after a long day of gambling. There is also a McDonalds and a couple of other fast food places, but we only ate at Starbucks and Sbarro. We chose to stay at the Monte Carlo for this Las Vegas trip because of the cheap price of only $59-$69 per night over Sunday, Monday and Tuesday nights. We stayed there before but had been avoiding this hotel the past few years because of its proximity to the City Center major construction project, but it seems to be almost done. We had a room facing the strip and I never hear any noise coming from the construction  it was very quiet. There is also a brand new parking garage that is well lit, has wide spaces and one of the cleanest garages I have experience in Las Vegas. I actually saw a security guard walking the garage unlike other properties where they just rest up in the guard hut and view surveillance videos. And the bridge that takes you from the garage to the hotel drops you off at the lobby and close to the elevators so you dont have to valet park or schlep your luggage through the casino if you choose not to use bell service.High speed internet was $14.99 per 24-hours. Overall this was a very enjoyable stay and we will definitely stay at Monte Carlo again if the price is right.

Sep 1 2009 	Nice hotel but not one of the best on the Strip	Stayed here for two nights in between out LA and Anaheim trip. Got a very good deal through Expedia NZ, around NZD100/night with USD25 food and beverages allowance.We were given a room on the 31st floor, which is just one floor short of the top level. Ours faced the swimming pool (more about it later), but we couldn't hear any music, maybe because it's so high up. What we could hear almost all the time was the beeping noise of construction vehicles from next door. They almost finish building the Aria and Mandarin Oriental next door but there was still some construction noise. One reviewer noted that water drains very slowly on the bathtub which we also experienced. However the toilet flushed with a lot of vigor, the water felt like being sucked at high speed!! Safe is provided in the room, TV is still CRT (no flat screen?), air conditioning is very good, and no refrigerator. Location wise, it's pretty handy to New York New York and MGM, but a long walk on the crowded footpath to other places north. This is especially exacerbated by the construction next door which reduces the width of the footpath. At the end we drove everywhere, and since self-parking is free, it was much more easier and stress-free. One warning, don't drive on the Strip itself, especially northbound after 6pm. You'll get stuck for hours!! We used the back road which connected the hotels.The hotel itself looks amazing from the outside, but once you're past the reception, everything becomes ordinary. The casino doesn't have anything special, there isn't any shopping centre (shops, 'cept for the hotel's one), the only food place that was open for 24hrs is Subway. Compared with Caesar's Palace, Bellagio, New York New York, the Monte Carlo is far behind.Parking was handy, we could find a park just outside the main entrance, no need for valet or parking inside the car park building.The pools are very average, and full of people sitting/standing around with their cocktails getting slowly drunk. They would give you a dirty look for having fun, I guess the whole thing is being targeted to the adults market and not families!We went for a buffet breakfast at the hotel since we had the $25 allowance, lots of good food at the buffet. Very attentive waiting staff, ours drinks were replenished all the time without being asked. I loved the omelette station, not really sure about having pizza for breakfast though. The pastries were very nice.

Aug 31 2009 	Good location OK rooms SCARY elevators and LOUD pool!	I am going back and forth between a two and three. I wouldn't choose to go here again or recommend it, but I wouldn't say "no" if someone paid for it or if it was a super killer deal to stay there again.My husband and I went with two other couples (celebrating a 40th birthday). Overall, the hotel was satisfactory. The rooms were not dirty, but I didn't exactly get a pristine feeling while there. The windows were dirty and like someone else mentioned, there was room service food sitting out in the hallway for at least 12 hours. The rooms are very normal. Nothing really interesting or special...in need of renovation. One of the couples in our group got a spa suite and ended up changing to a regular room. My friend said, "It was nicely decorated......for my 90 year old grandmother." Also, we had a room facing the pool (TEN flights up) and we could hear the club music from the pool....loud and clear (nothing like trying to catch a catnap to a DJ mix of Journey and Lady Gaga)The pools were nice. You MUST get there ASAP to get lounge chairs together if you have a group. Like everyone else has said and I mentioned above, they now have club music blaring from noon until five. I didn't mind the music THAT much, but the pool was very packed full of party people. I really couldn't see letting my kids stay in the pool after noon or so. It got really crowded and people just stand around in the lazy river on the one side. Most people just walk it at that time, If you try to ride a tube, the drunks give you dirty looks for running into them while they stand there drinking their $17 speciality drinks. Pool closes at seven...which I think seems a bit early, but that could be normal for Vegas.The casino itself is OK. Nothing to write home about. The hallway outside of Diablos (as well as parts of the pool area) DO smell like rotten eggs, The casino itself is a bit stale in smell and decor. They pump in that gross headache producing air freshener which gets annoying. Watch out for the elevators. My friend was riding down from her room and the elevator lost control at least a floor or more from ground level and they fell/crashed to the ground. No one was hurt (jarred and sore, but not hurt) but they were stuck for about 45 minutes....little fresh air for most of that time, and grown men crying. The phone did not work and no one could get a signal. Despite all that, the casino did do what they could to get them out ASAP and my friend got a $100 comp at Brand. I don't think this is completely settled yet since it was just a couple days ago. They tool everyone's info down. Which leads us to our largest gripe. The watistaff at Brand was pretty stuck up at best and downright rude at worst. Brand supposedly is not "affiliated" with Monte Carlo. Yeah, I know it may be its own entity, but it RESIDES in the MC. I am not sure how it isn't affiliated with the hotel. ::eye roll:::When my friend explained to the waitress what happened to her (the elevator incident), and told her that they had a $100 comp there and to just charge it to her room and the hotel is going to take care of it, the waitress became pretty belligerent and looked at us like we were lying. She kept saying they "Were not affiliated" and my friend kept saying that she knew that and that it didn't matter. The hotel was going to cover it and to call ____ at the front desk if she had questions. The waitress was still weird about it and my friend said sarcastically something like, "wow, your empathy is amazing, thanks" A few minutes later (before we got our drinks) we saw the waitress retelling the story to her manager (we are pretty sure that is what she was doing because she was pretty worked up and animated.)I know, long story, but it was rude. The drinks were good and we had apps there the day before (waitress was fairly stuck up then too) and they were fine....nothing exciting or original, but OK. I would spend your money at a steakhouse like Craftsteak rather than wasting it at a wannabe steakhouse like that. We have all kinds of snobby wannabe hipster places back home and there are running rampant in Vegas... spend the money and go for the real deal instead.One last thing..we did have a few really nice waitresses in the casino itself. The pretty blond mom of a 14 year old (was getting off of work to take her back to school shopping) who showed my friends how to figure out the 1cent slots was such a sweetie (worked Thursday and Friday night). I wish I remembered her name. Thanks anyway!

Aug 30 2009 	If you want to stay in an MGM Mirage Resort choose the Bellagio	Two months prior to our trip to Las Vegas, we began searching online for a great hotel deal. Having traveled to Vegas twice in the past, I knew the layout of the Strip and knew that the Monte Carlo appeared both nice on the outside and nice in the lobby. We happened upon a great deal for a Monaco Suite at the hotel and booked it for 3 nights. A few days after booking, I noticed the reviews on this website and began to have second thoughts about staying at the resort. However, I decided to stay put and keep my reservation and wait until I checked in to make an opinion of the Monte Carlo for myself.The big day arrived and our flight arrived in Las Vegas early. Baggage claim was a breeze and we immediately chartered a Town Car at the airport to take us to the Monte Carlo. We arrived and proceeded to registration which was not very busy. I was pleased to see so many clerks working behind the desk and how clean the lobby was. We checked in immediately during which I asked where our room would be located, which was a low floor, and I asked to be placed higher. The clerk asked if floor 13 would be ok, to which I should have said no as that proved to be the omen for the resort. The room was on the pool side and I asked if there was anything else after having read the reviews on how loud the pool DJ can be. The clerk said no and that we would be moved to another room the next day facing the strip. Our room wasn't quite clean yet, which was no big deal as it was only 11 in the morning. We proceeded to the Forum Shops to have lunch at Spago and returned to the Monte Carlo around 1 p.m.We immediately made it to our room, which was conveniently located beside the elevators and opened the door. The sound of the pool music was much worse that I had anticipated. The view of City Center construction was awful as well. I was livid. I called the front desk to ask if I could be moved only to be told that there was nothing available. Having been told earlier that we would be moving the next day to another room I didn't want to unpack and sat down on the couch. That is when I noticed an unusual stain on the sofa that appeared to be a bodily fluid. At this point I was more livid. We left the hotel room, because it was so loud and began walking the strip to see what was going on. A couple hours prior to our dinner reservation, we returned to the hotel to change for dinner. Before boarding the elevator, we stopped by the registration desk to alert the staff of the bodily fluid and the pool music. They immediately moved us to a room facing the New York New York on a higher floor. However, when we walked up to the door, I noticed a room service tray sitting beside the door (Yes the other reviews of room service trays being left for days are in fact true). We opened the door and noticed lights on in the powder room, and ice bucket full of ice, an open bottle of water, and the adjoining room door open. Even more livid, we called the front desk and they moved us back down to the 12th floor back to the pool side. When we got to our room, the keys didn't work and a maintenance employee had to let us in. The furniture was tattered and looked as if it had seen better days. The Monaco Suite has potential. The rooms are spacious and having two bathrooms is a plus. However, t the Monte Carlo doesn't care to go the extra mile to reach that higher level.When we finally arrived in our final room we called to the front desk to alert them that we would only stay 1 night, as we had no time to change hotels before getting ready for dinner, and would check out in the morning. A manager asked what he could do to fix the problem, but never really offered much to keep us as customers. With over 3,000 hotel rooms, I know that the Monte Carlo had something better that they could have offered us, even if it meant paying more. They didn't offer to change our room type at all. The next day we checked out which was an easy process and checked into the Bellagio. The experience was much different and I recommend to anyone to go ahead and book the Bellagio before settling on the Monte Carlo

Aug 26 2009 	a little worn	the monte carlo is showing it's age on the strip, the hotel rooms are a bit worn down, but maybe i'm judging it unfairly as i stayed in suites at the venetian, mgm suites, and planet hollywood, last time few times i was in town. room was very ordinary, with worn linens and small television. bathroom was aged with a tub that drained so slow the water would rise up whenever you took a shower. asked engineering to help, but they said that was the normal drainage rate. casino was quite a bit quiet than i'm used to, not a particularly attractive or hip crown. well, at least it's better than circus circus.

Aug 26 2009 	Good location everything else average	Stayed at the Monte Carlo at the beginning of August. I am on their email list and booked directly thru their website when they emailed a good deal of 4 nights (including a Saturday) for approx $260 total. We checked in on Saturday around 2 pm, and only had to wait a few minutes before it was our turn. Jody, who checked us in, and every other employee we encountered during our stay proved to be very friendly and customer service oriented. Our request for a king bed, non-smoking room was accommodated, and we ended up with a handicapped room on the 19th floor for no extra charge. We had a view of the City Center and the pool. As some have mentioned, the pool music was definitely audible from even the 19th floor- but it was only especially loud on Saturday and Sunday. Noise from construction was only a problem on the last day of our stay, the back-up beeping from the dump trucks started at about 630 a.m. that day. The room itself was very clean, the pillows and bedding definitely need updating, but at least I didnt see any stains, etc. The maid service was great, we left off the Do Not Disturb sign on our 3rd day, and our towels were refreshed and bed made by the time we got back a few hours later. The a/c was sort of odd, it never really got cold in the room even when we turned it down to 60 one night. And either the sink or the toilet in the bathroom gave off a faint sewage smell the whole time we were there.I used the fitness center one day for $19 per day. It has everything you need for a good workout: free weights, exercise balls, cables, and a whole line of circuit equipment with at least one machine for each muscle group. The treadmills were fairly new looking and they had bikes, ellipticals and a stepmill as well. I could never fathom paying $19 per day to use a gym in my regular life, but this was Vegas and I have read that most hotel fitness centers on the strip are priced similarly. We won the most money playing downtown, the difference was amazing. Slots on the strip are especially tight. Walking along the strip is sort of a mess right now with the City Center construction but when its all done I am sure it will look great. It also seemed like the timeshare people, porn card flickers, nightclub and show ticket sellers that stand on the strip yelling at you are more plentiful and aggressive than compared to our trip last October. I felt like I was saying No, thanks to someone every few feet.

Made sure my towels were really wet and left on the floor to get new ones and wiped up floor myself, bit grossed out. Thought leaving a housekeeping tip may help turns out the only tips I should have left was how to clean....Also the smell of smoke was so over-powering in our non-smoking room I had to sleep with the sheet up to my nose to filter the air.... Best part of our stay was the location ..and we were so pleased with the breakfast and staff at the cafe within the hotel that we ate there twice. Don't bother here unless you brought your cleaning supplies and room spray with you.

Aug 24 2009 	You get what you pay for...	I just got back from staying at the Monte Carlo with my sister. We checked in at around 1 in the morning and their was 5 people working the front desk. NONE of them actually checked anyone in they were "busy" ( 2 rude girls of the girls flirting with the other 3 guys). One girl finally took us. It took 50 minutes to check us in. Not one other person was checking in, it was quite ridiculous. We had ordered a fridge didn't come until the next day after we had to call. They didn't leave us a single roll of toilet paper, and we upgraded to a higher floor to get a more recently renovated room... i'd hate to see what the other rooms look like. Although a pool drink is $17 for a large, I'd suggest bringing your own booze in a water bottle down to the pool! This didn't bother us but it might bother some people. Also, make sure you check your credit card both my sister and I got charged extra (ex. a fridge is 15 a night we had it for 2 nights but got charged $55?!? and on both of our credit cards) Its a shame, the hotel could be great but is in need of a facelift. It's worth it to pay a little bit more and get better service.

Aug 23 2009 	2nd stay a complete disappointment.	this was my 2nd stay here. the repeat visit because of the good time i had the first time. first the room we were promised wasnt available unless we payed $40 simply because the room was on the "upper floors". then once we got to our substarndard room, the a/c was weak at best... in hot las vegas. the bath tub drain was plugged. had to call maintance 3x. the bed wasnt made one time by housekeeping on a 5 day trip. i couldnt take a towel from the pool to the room, so i had to walk through the casino back to the room all wet. many disappointing things. there are a lot of places to stay on the strip. if i had this last trip to do over again the monte carlo wouldnt be part of it

Aug 23 2009 	Like The Whole Strip Not What It Was	On a cross country trip stayed 2 nights. We arrived late on a Saturday night and were surprised by how fast check in was. Aug 22 2009 	black mold in the shower stall	beautiful lobby,pool,casino-walking your family thru the casino to get to the strip very nice atmosphere-fast food at the food court good selection but appeared to be grungy behind the counters-the pool area is very cramped with tons of loungers which by the way you will not find one if you dont line up in the a.m. (8:30 of so-pool opens at 9:00) the pool atmosphere is unfriendly and for the young single crowd or young couples who want to see and be seen-the rooms were lovely and the beds appeared very clean and they were comfortable-the bathroom was puzzling to me-how could such a beautiful hotel allow there to be black mold growing in the shower -ever heard of Tilex one spray and its gone-also other peoples hairs in the just cleaned bath?? beware if this is not acceptable to you

Aug 21 2009 	Good deals nothing fancy	We liked this hotel. If you are looking for a good deal, the Monte Carlo would be my choice. Nice, plain, clean rooms. Aug 21 2009 	Smoke filled rooms	I could smell cigarette smoke from the room vent. Aug 21 2009 	Great location on strip. Staff excellent.	Recently stayed here on the Summer Escape package. Cheap rooms with discount coupons. Checked in immediately upon arrival with no problems. Aug 19 2009 	It was great	My family enjoyed our stay at the Monte Carlo, It was a wonderful experience. The rooms were clean and the housekeeping was wonderful too. Aug 19 2009 	Good clean comfortable adequate................but that's all	Arrived late afternoon, not too bad a wait at reception, all went well booking in, asked for the discounts that were advertised on line, given a book of vouchers. Discount vouchers were ok but only used 2, one for buffet breakfast (two for one) which was superb, choice is amazing (but after two days really wanted just a bowl of cereal and cold milk) The other voucher used was for two for the price of one for the Lance Burton Show which was superb. Aug 17 2009 	Great Stay in Monaco Suite!	I stayed here for 6 nights in June. It was my second tim in Vegas; and we had a great time!. Aug 17 2009 	Not bad - shame about the Pool Parties	The hotel is pretty good, small in comparison to others on the strip, but that is quite nice. Aug 16 2009 	Not quite a 4-star	The lobby/casino/restaurant areas may give off the appearance of a 4-star, but that rating does not apply when it comes to the rooms. + SWIMMING POOLS: Lazy Pool and Wave Pool + LOCATION: on the Strip, across from Hard Rock Cafe, next door to NY NY. (a 15-20 min walk will get you to Paris, Planet Hollywood, and Bellagio) During our visit, Las Vegas Blvd. was under a bit of construction and the sidewalks were sheltered and barricaded along the boulevard.- HOUSEKEEPING: worn out bedspread, stain on flat sheet, hair still on bathroom floor, cruddy caulk around the tub, stained carpet- ROOM DECOR: old-school TV, no coffee maker, missing ice bucketBottom line: Great location and pools, but not worth the "4-star" rate and ratings. Aug 14 2009 	Don't waste your money here!	The lobby is the most attractive part of this hotel. Rooms are poorly lighted. Hallways and other common areas are dirty. Aug 14 2009 	Housekeeping gets an F - Pool area gets a D	The hotel would get an A for convenience regarding the distance from the hotel rooms to the casino and pool and lobby. very convenient, very friendly hosts. 'the day before we left housekeeping didnt come and clean until past 7 pm and in fact we saw them on our floor and had to ask if they could at least give us some towels so we could shower go to the pool and restaurant and there was a male housekeeper we asked who was obviously taking care of our floor and who did an awful job. Aug 13 2009	Not Bad Probably Would Return	stayed here for my cousin's wedding and we had a good time. my only complaint was that the rooms weren't the cleanest as I found food wrappers under the bed when we checked in. also, they used a flat sheet as a fitted sheet when making the bed (not a big deal to us but a hotel that size should have plenty of fitted sheets). there was also a lot construction going on and the pool was closed (big disapointment). overall it was an impersonal nice stay on the strip. wouldn't be my first choice when i go back but it's not bad.

Aug 13 2009 	Upgrade your room	When my wife and I went to check in, we were asked if we'd like to pay to upgrade our room. They told us at the front desk that they had no king rooms available, but after we told them the room was unacceptable, they offered us a king room. We said that no matter what, we didn't want a room of that quality, so we paid $70/night to be upgraded to a mini suite that was much nicer.
